intro: Castilleja fissifolia var. integrifolia, commonly known as the Sierra red sacro, is a hemiparasitic flowering plant native to the western United States. It belongs to the Orobanchaceae family and is characterized by its bright red to orange flowers that bloom in late spring to early summer. The plant has slender, branched stems and lacks true leaves, relying on its roots to absorb nutrients from host plants. It typically grows in open, sunny habitats such as meadows and grasslands. Its unique ecological role involves forming symbiotic relationships with various grasses and shrubs.
